page.title: 01GOSBERTON VILLAGE
page.content: This part of Gosberton is dominated by the large, very beauutiful church of St. Peter and St. Paul of the Norman, decorated and perpendicular periods. Close to the church is Gosberton House, a Georgian house in a park, it has had additions built and is now a school for the educationally sub-normal. There is a large amount of residential developmenting the village, it has a compact shopping centre and good bus service. The land is very flat, very fertile and extensively farmed. Crops grown are potatoes, sugar beet, wheat, vegetables, tulips and daffodils. Most of the farms are quite small, 50 to 100 acres. Because the land is low it has to be well drained and the fields are surrounded by "dykes" which carry the surplus water out to the wash. Many of the residents of Gosberton
